{{Infobox cricket ground | ground_name = Bat and Ball Ground | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = | caption = | country = England | location = [[Gravesend, Kent]] | coordinates = {{coord|51.437|N|0.365|E|type:landmark|display=title, inline}} | establishment = 1845 | demolished = | last used = | seating_capacity = | owner = [[Gravesend Cricket Club]] | architect = | contractor = | operator = | tenants = | home club = | county club = | end1 = | end2 = | year1 = 1849–1971 | club1 = [[Kent County Cricket Club]] | year2 = 1880–present | club2 = [[Gravesend Cricket Club]] | date = 25 November | year = 2017 | source = https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/503.html CricketArchive }}
The '''Bat and Ball Ground''' is a [[cricket]] and sports ground in [[Gravesend, Kent|Gravesend]] in [[Kent]]. The ground was used as a [[first-class cricket]] venue by [[Kent County Cricket Club]] between 1849 and 1971. It remains in use by [[Gravesend Cricket Club]] who have used the ground as their home since their formation in 1880. The site also has [[lawn bowls]] and [[tennis]] facilities and is the home of Gravesend Bowls Club.<ref name=gbc>[https://democracy.gravesham.gov.uk/Published/C00000106/M00000728/AI00002085/$BatandBall2.docA.ps.pdf Planning application], [[Gravesham Borough Council]], July 2007. Retrieved 2017-11-25.</ref>
The ground is situated south of Gravesend town centre on the western side of the [[A227 road|A227 Wrotham Road]]. The Bat and Ball Inn, which was named after the ground, is on the eastern side of the ground.<ref name=osx162>Explorer Map 162 – Greenwich & Gravesend, [[Ordnance Survey]], 2015-09-16.</ref>
==Cricketing history== The first recorded cricket match on the site of the ground was in 1840 when a Gravesend team played Penenden Heath.<ref name=camisc>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/503_misc.html Other matches played on Bat and Ball Ground], CricketArchive. Retrieved 2017-11-25.</ref> It is believed by local historians that a new wicket was laid down at the ground in 1845 by [[Tom Adams (cricketer)|Tom Adams]] who had played for Kent sides before and after the formation the County Club in 1842. The cricket ground was laid out in the grounds of Ruckland House, described as a "large mansion",<ref name=gbc /><ref name=graves38>[http://www.discovergravesham.co.uk/gravesend-chronology/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=106:1838-1852&catid=44&Itemid=225 1838–1852], Discover Gravesham, Gravesham Borough Council. Retrieved 2017-11-25.</ref> and used as the private cricket ground for the house.<ref name=miltonacs>Milton H (1979) Kent cricket grounds, in ''The Cricket Statistician'', no. 28, December 1979, pp.2–10.</ref> It was later owned by the [[Earl of Darnley|Darnley family]] from [[Cobham Hall]] to the south of Gravesend, and by the Billings family.<ref name=miltonacs />
[[Kent County Cricket Club]] first used the ground in 1849 for a match against an All-England Eleven in the grounds first [[first-class cricket]] match. From 1849 to 1971 the ground was the venue for 142{{efn-ua|name=matches}} first-class matches for Kent,<ref name=17annual210>Grounds records in ''Kent County Cricket Club Annual 2017'', pp.210–211. Canterbury: [[Kent County Cricket Club]].</ref> the last of which saw them play the [[Pakistani cricket team in England in 1971|touring Pakistan team in 1971]].<ref name=fcm>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/503_f.html First-Class Matches played on Bat and Ball Ground], CricketArchive. Retrieved 2017-11-25.</ref> The ground was used regularly for [[County Championship]] matches by Kent between the start of the Championship in 1890 and 1970 with one or two matches scheduled by the county at the ground in almost every season.<ref name=fcm /> Kent played [[Australian cricket team in England in 1893|the touring Australian side]] on the ground in 1893 and two matches were played by the [[South of England cricket team]] against Australian tourists in [[Australian cricket team in England in 1884|1884]] and [[Australian cricket team in England in 1886|1886]].<ref name=fcm />
Non-first class matches held on the ground include one of the first matches played by the [[Australian Aboriginal cricket team in England in 1868|Australian Aboriginal team which toured England in 1868]] – the first tour by any Australian side. The team had arrived at Gravesend and were taken to lunch at the Bat and Ball inn next to the ground.<ref name=bbc9jul13>Ricketts O (2013) [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-23225434 Aboriginal cricket: The first Australian tour of England, 1868], [[BBC News]], 2013-07-09. Retrieved 2017-11-25.</ref><ref name=gravesham>[http://www.discovergravesham.co.uk/gravesend-chronology/1853-1872.html 1853 - 1872], Discover Gravesham, [[Gravesham Borough Council]]. Retrieved 2017-11-25.</ref> The first matches on the tours of England by the [[West Indian cricket team in England in 1933|West Indies in 1933]] and [[Indian cricket team in England in 1936|Indian team in 1936]] were at the ground, both against teams organised by Kent great [[Tich Freeman]], and the [[West Indian cricket team in England in 1939|West Indian tourists of 1939]] played against a team organised by [[Les Ames]] at the Bat and Ball Ground. In [[West Indian cricket team in England in 1963|1963 the West Indies]] returned again to play the [[Club Cricket Conference]].<ref name=camisc />
The ground has also played host to 24 matches involving the Kent Second XI in the [[Minor Counties Championship]] and [[Second XI Championship]].<ref name=camcc>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/503_minc.html Minor Counties Championship Matches played on Bat and Ball Ground], CricketArchive. Retrieved 2017-11-25.</ref><ref>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/503_sec.html Second XI Championship Matches played on Bat and Ball Ground], CricketArchive. Retrieved 2017-11-25.</ref> In local cricket, the ground is the home venue of [[Gravesend Cricket Club]] who play in the [[Kent Cricket League]].<ref name=gcc>[http://www.gravesendcc.co.uk/default.aspx Welcome to Gravesend Cricket Club], [[Gravesend Cricket Club]]. Retrieved 2017-11-25.</ref><ref name=ko30dec11>[http://www.kentonline.co.uk/gravesend/news/olympic-cash-boost-for-gravesend-a68529/ Olympic cash boost for Gravesend Cricket Club], ''[[Kent Online]]'', 2011-12-30. Retrieved 2017-11-25.</ref><ref name=jgc>[http://www.jgcsportsturf.com/gravesend-cricket-wicket-project The Gravesend Project], JGC Sports Turf. Retrieved 2017-11-25.</ref>
==Records on the ground== A total of 145 games classified by sources as first-class cricket matches were played on the ground. All except two matches featured Kent as the home side.{{efn-ua|name=matches|CricketArchive lists 143 matches played by Kent sides on the ground. [[Kent County Cricket Club]] sources detail 142 matches played by the club on the ground. Kent do not include a number of matches played by the county in the 19th century where 13 or more players were included in the Kent side as first-class matches. These are accepted as first-class matches by some other sources.<ref name=18annual141>Kent Records, in ''Kent County Cricket Club Annual 2018'', p.141. Canterbury: [[Kent County Cricket Club]].</ref> An 1854 match between a Kent XV and a United England Eleven took place on the ground which is not classified as a first-class match by Kent sources.<ref name=ca1854>[https://web.archive.org/web/20160314011044/http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/1/1018.html Kent v United England Eleven], CricketArchive. Archived 2016-03-14. Retrieved 2018-05-26.</ref>}} The [[South of England cricket team]] played two first-class matches on the ground in the 1880s.<ref name=fcm /> *Highest total: 561 by [[Kent County Cricket Club|Kent]] against [[Nottinghamshire County Cricket Club|Nottinghamshire]], 1908 *Lowest total: 18 by Kent against [[Sussex County Cricket Club|Sussex]], 1867 *Highest partnership: 296, 4th wicket by [[Kenneth Hutchings|KL Hutchings]] and [[Frank Woolley|FE Woolley]], for Kent against [[Northamptonshire County Cricket Club|Northants]], 1908 *Highest individual score: 257, [[WG Grace]] for [[Gloucestershire County Cricket Club|Gloucestershire]] against Kent, 1895 *Best bowling in an innings: 8/40, [[Tich Freeman|AP Freeman]] for Kent against [[Leicestershire County Cricket Club|Leicestershire]], 1935 *Best bowling in a match: 15/142, AP Freeman for Kent against [[Essex County Cricket Club|Essex]], 1931
==Other uses== The ground has been used for a number of sports and was used during the winter by Gravesend Hockey Club for a number of years for [[field hockey]] matches. It has also been used for school sports, [[association football]], [[rugby union]] and was flooded and used as an ice skating rink during the harsh winter of 1895.<ref name=miltonacs />
==Notes== {{notelist-ua}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Briggs Rd Sporting Complex | nickname = | image = Briggs Rd Sporting Complex.jpg | location = [[Ipswich, Queensland]] | coordinates = {{coord|27|38|24|S|152|45|41|E|region:AU-QLD_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | opened = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[City of Ipswich]] | operator = | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Western Pride FC]] | seating_capacity = 3,500 }} '''Briggs Road Sporting Complex''' is an [[Association football]] stadium located in the [[Ipswich, Queensland]] suburb of [[Flinders View]].
The ground is home to [[Western Pride FC]], which plays in the Australian second-tier [[National Premier Leagues Queensland]] competition.
The facility contains three rectangular fields and a training area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ipswich.qld.gov.au/about_ipswich/parks_reserves_precincts/parks_search/briggs-road-sporting-complex|website=Ipswich City Council|title=Briggs Road Sporting Complex|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
Briggs Road Sporting Complex forms a larger sporting precinct with the neighbouring Ipswich Hockey Complex, which together have been used for sporting carnivals and regional trials.
== History ==
Briggs Road Sporting Complex was the home of Ipswich Junior [[Rugby League]] and briefly state league side [[Ipswich Jets]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportingpulse.com/get_file.cgi?id=1145673|website=Ipswich Rugby League Inc.|title=Ipswich Rugby League Inc.|publisher=Sporing Pulse}}</ref> It hosted the 2012 [[Murri Rugby League Carnival]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.murrirugbyleague.com.au/2012league.html|website=Murri Rugby League|title=www.murrirugbyleague.com.au/2012league.html}}</ref>
On Wednesday May 18, 2016, a crowd of reported variously as between 1200 and 3200 watched Western Pride FC played [[New Zealand national football team]] with the visitors winning 2-0.<ref>{{cite web|title=Preparing To Face The Best|url=http://www.qt.com.au/news/preparing-to-face-the-best/3030177/|website=The Queensland Times}}</ref>
On Saturday 1st September 2017, a crowd of 3383 watched Western Pride win the [[National Premier Leagues Queensland]] Grand Final against [[Moreton Bay United FC]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.qt.com.au/news/japan-next-mission-for-ipswichs-best-football-side/3219550/|title=Japan next mission for Ipswich's best football side|last=Lems|first=David|work=Queensland Times|access-date=2017-09-04|language=en}}</ref>
== Neville T. Bonner Building ==
The grandstand and clubhouse is named after Ipswich resident Senator [[Neville Bonner]], the first of the country's [[indigenous Australians]] to be become a member of the [[Australian Parliament]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ipswich.qld.gov.au/about_council/media/articles/2008/briggs-road-rededicated-to-football|website=Ipswich City Council|title=Briggs Road Rededicated to football}}</ref>
The clubhouse features a function room, canteen and bar.
==References==

{{Infobox national volleyball team |name=Costa Rica |gender=women |image=Flag of Costa Rica.svg |federation=Federación Costarricense de Voleibol |website= |confederation=NORCECA |manager=William Corrales |coach=Braulio Godínez Blanco |Olympic apps= }} The '''Costa Rica women's national volleyball team''' represents [[Costa Rica]] in international women's [[volleyball]] competitions and friendly matches.
At the [[Women's NORCECA Volleyball Championship]], Costa Rica usually competes for places 5-8. In 2013, then head coach [[Horacio Bastit]] stated that a better finish was not yet realistic. He stated that beating teams such as [[United States women's national volleyball team|the US]], [[Canada women's national volleyball team|Canada]], [[Puerto Rico women's national volleyball team|Puerto Rico]] or [[Dominican Republic women's national volleyball team|the Dominican Republic]] can remain as goals for the future.<ref>German Matamoros S., [https://www.nacion.com/puro-deporte/otros-deportes/seleccion-femenina-de-voleibol-de-costa-rica-viajara-al-norceca-con-la-ilusion-de-un-mejor-papel/4LDWME76FJEK5LKNJO5E2RWJIA/story/ Selección femenina de voleibol de Costa Rica viajará al Norceca con la ilusión de un mejor papel], La Nación, 14 September 2013. Retrieved 03 November 2018. {{es icon}}</ref>

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = East End Park | image = PendletonPark1.JPG | image_size = 250px | location = Ridgeley Street, Humbert Street, Babb Alley & Watson Street in [[Cincinnati]] | broke_ground = 1891 | opened = April 25, 1891 | closed = August 13, 1891 | demolished = Unknown | owner = [[Cincinnati Kelly's Killers]] | operator = [[Cincinnati Kelly's Killers]] | surface = Grass | architect = [[Al Marcus]] | other_names = Pendleton Park, East End Grounds & Association Park | tenants = [[Cincinnati Kelly's Killers]] | seating_capacity = 5,000}}
'''East End Park''' is a former [[major league baseball]] [[baseball park|park]] located in the [[East End, Cincinnati|East End]] neighborhood of [[Cincinnati]] in the United States.<ref>http://www.retrosheet.org/boxesetc/P/PK_PEN01.htm</ref><ref>http://www.scsr.org/19CCBB/Ballparks/EEP.htm</ref> <!-- Image with unknown copyright status removed: [[File:East End Park (High Shot).jpg|thumb|left|250px|The spot where East End Park once stood.]] --> The ballpark, which is also known to baseball historians as '''Pendleton Park''', was home to the Cincinnati Reds of the [[American Association (19th century)|American Association]] (now more commonly known as the [[Cincinnati Kelly's Killers]]) during the 1891 baseball season. The club was led by the flamboyant star, [[King Kelly|Mike "King" Kelly]].
==The Reds' of 1891==
The east side Reds had no relationship to the current [[Cincinnati Reds]] team. Those Reds had transferred from the Association to the [[National League]] in 1890. With the League and the Association on bad terms following several years of peace and [[Players' League]] stress of 1890, the Association decided to field a team of its own in Cincinnati for 1891.
This peculiar situation gave the city of Cincinnati two major league baseball teams in the same year with the same nickname. The National League Reds, who played on the west side of Cincinnati; and the Association Reds who played on the east side. Adding to the confusion was the presence of another Reds team in the Association, the [[Boston Reds (1890–1891)|Boston Reds]]. All of these Reds teams derived their nicknames, indirectly, from the original [[Cincinnati Red Stockings]] of 1869–1870.
The east side Reds team has also been referred to as '''Kelly's Killers''' and the Cincinnati '''Porkers''', as well as Kelly's Wonders, Kelly's Braves and Kelly's Hustlers. Some historians have extended the best known of these informal names by calling them the "Cincinnati Kelly's Killers". However, the Cincinnati papers who covered the team in 1891 only occasionally referred to the club by any of these nicknames.
==Pendleton Park / East End Park== Kelly's search for a suitable playing field led him to what was then the far east end of the city, in a picturesque location along the [[Ohio River]] that was known as '''Pendleton Park''' or '''Pendleton Grounds'''. The club secured a lease and built a small ballpark within Pendleton Park, which was dubbed '''East End Park''' by the media.
The location of the park was just off Eastern Avenue (now called Riverside Drive), where the '''Schmidt Recreation Complex''' is currently located. The ballpark was located between modern day Humbert Street (southwest, right field); Babb (or Babby) Alley (northeast, some distance beyond third base); Watson Street (southeast, left field); and Ridgeley Street (northwest, first base). Ridgeley street now dead ends at Babby Alley but it once extended the distance of the third base bleachers. The diamond was situated toward the northwest (or actually north-northwest) corner of the block.
Just south of Humbert is the Ohio River. Many patrons attending east end Reds games were dropped off by steamboat, coming either from the city or from [[Coney Island, Cincinnati, Ohio|Coney Island]]. East End Park was one of only a handful of major league parks to have access by way of a river.
==The Reds Were Blue on Sundays==
At the time, the National League did not allow Sunday baseball games to be played. As a result, the rival American Association capitalized on this by having their teams play Sunday games. However, the Cincinnati Association club had difficulty with this because the city had the [[blue law]] in place which also disallowed Sunday games. Owners of the Cincinnati Reds made repeated attempts at playing games on Sundays. Sometimes the Mayor of Cincinnati, Mayor [[John B. Mosby]], would enforce the law and other times he would not. When the Mayor did enforce the law, the Reds and their opponents found themselves in jail.
In one instance, before a game played on May 24 against the Philadelphia Athletics, the Chief of Police behaved like a Colonel in the US Army. Dressed in a full military uniform, Chief Dietsch had seventy-five of his police officers march back and forth on the baseball field prior to game time to try to intimidate the baseball club. He even went as far as to have seventy-five more police officers waiting at the station if the Reds attempted to play. The players went ahead and attempted to play anyway. When the game entered the second half of the first inning, Chief Deitsch had enough and had his officers arrest all of the players. The next day the Cincinnati Commercial Gazette reported that "It would be commendable in Chief Deitsch if he would display as much zeal in closing saloons and shutting off a few of the crap games that he has shown in stopping Sunday base ball." <ref>http://www.scsr.org/19CCBB/Teams/CR4/1891/BS/05/24.htm</ref><ref>''Cincinnati Commercial Gazette'', May 25, 1891</ref>
==Demise of Mike Kelly's "Killers"==
The east side Reds ballpark proved to be too remote for drawing fans consistently and as a result the club did not fare very well at the box office. During a day off on August 17, it was decided to suspend operations of the franchise until a new ballpark could be built on the west side of town. Ownership was planning to reactivate the club for the start of the 1892 baseball season. The final Reds game played at East End Park was on August 13 against the Boston Reds. The game resulted in a 1-7 Cincinnati loss. The club's final game was on the road with an 8-0 loss to the [[St. Louis Browns (NL)|St. Louis Browns]] on August 16, 1891, in St. Louis.
The Milwaukee Brewers of the Western League stepped in and finished out the Reds schedule. Several of Mike Kelly's Reds joined the Milwaukee club including business manager [[Frank Bancroft]]. The Brewers played their first game on the 18th, again in St. Louis. Kelly was not among the new club's members, as he returned to his familiar home in Boston to resume his career, playing with the AA's Boston Reds club and then finishing the season with the Boston Beaneaters of the NL.
Kelly's Beaneaters won the League pennant while the Boston Reds would go on to win the Association pennant. This proved to be the last hurrah for the Association, which merged with the National League during the off-season. With a Cincinnati team already in the National League, the Cincinnati Association franchise was done.
==Aftermath and legacy==
[[File:East End Park (High Shot).jpg|thumb|left|250px|The site of East End Park as it looks today.]]
In 1896, a few years after the short-lived experiment with major league baseball on the east side of Cincinnati failed, the Pendleton grounds were acquired by the [[Cincinnati Gymnasium and Athletic Club]], and became known as the '''Cincinnati Gym Grounds'''. The Athletic Club retained the ballfield and grandstand, and built a swimming pool in the center field area near the clubhouse building.
The East End ballpark suffered severe damage following flooding in the spring of 1897, situated as it was in the floodplain of the Ohio River. The outfield wall and bleachers were swept out into the Ohio River, leaving just the grandstand, pavilion and club house. All were restored during late spring of 1897 and were ready for use again.<ref>Cincinnati Commercial Gazette | May 16, 1897</ref>
The ballpark was considered for use as a temporary home for the National League Reds in 1900, after [[Crosley Field|League Park]] was severely damaged by fire the night of May 27–28. The Reds instead chose to play their games on the road for the next month until their own park could be sufficiently restored.<ref name="rhodes133">Rhodes, p. 133</ref>
Cincinnati's Board of Park Commissioners and Park Department proposed a concrete sidewalk to be created and that it extend the length of the park bordering with Eastern Avenue to provide a place for people to walk to and from work; however a 10-foot artificial stone sidewalk was established.<ref name="annual190137">Annual Report 1901, p. 37</ref><ref name="annual190739">Annual Report 1907, p. 39</ref> Thoughts of improving the grounds were not welcomed as the annual flooding prevents permanent structures from being built. Benches that had been placed the year before were washed away by the recent floods.<ref name=annual190739/>
The larger park area once known as Pendleton Park (which historians often present as the name for the ballpark itself) still exists and is currently known as '''Schmidt Recreation Complex''' or Schmidt Recreation Center, which has four softball diamonds, two of them overlapping the East End Park site, and two of them further west within the park.
The current softball field known as C.L. Harrison Field approximates the original orientation of the diamond, only somewhat farther to the north. The photographic evidence indicates that the original 1891 diamond was located in what would be the right field area of the Harrison field. In the opposite corner of the property, another softball field, the current Paul Kramer Field, occupies what was once the outfield area of East End Park.
The surroundings of the park are not significantly different from the 1890s. A number of the nearby houses still stand. Aerial views from Google maps indicate that water from the Ohio still wreaks occasional havoc with the ballfields there.
Only a small number of major league baseball fields from the 1890s survive as athletic fields (Cleveland's [[League Park]], and St. Louis' [[Sportsman's Park]], for example.). The two softball diamonds occupying East End Park's footprint allow the visitor a rare opportunity to imagine major league baseball being played there, over a century earlier.

''Annual Report of the Park Department of the City of Cincinnati''. *Cincinnati (Ohio). Board of Park Commissioners, Cincinnati (Ohio). Park Dept, Cincinnati (Ohio). Board of Park Trustees. 1907. ''Annual Report''. *Rhodes, Greg;Snyder, John. 2000. ''Redleg Journal: Year by Year and Day by Day With the Cincinnati Reds Since 1866''. Road West Publishing Company. {{ISBN|0-9641402-5-X}}. ;Specific {{reflist}}

{{Infobox stadium | name = Firestone Stadium | nickname = | image = Firestone Stadium CIMG7643.JPG | caption = Exterior, 2007 | fullname = | former_names = | location = 1575 Firestone Parkway
[[Akron, Ohio]] 44301
[[United States]] | coordinates = {{coord|41.041816|-81.528599|type:landmark|display=inline, title |format=dms}} | pushpin_map = USA | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = Location in the United States | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1925 | renovated = | expanded = | owner = [[Akron, Ohio|City of Akron]] | operator = [[Akron Racers]] | surface = Natural grass | scoreboard = Electronic | estimated_cost = | suites = | architect = | capacity = 4,576 | record_attendance = 6,256 (2008) | executive_suites = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[Akron Racers]] ([[National Pro Fastpitch|NPF]]) (1999–2018) }} '''Firestone Stadium''' is a baseball and softball stadium located in [[Akron, Ohio]], United States. The stadium was dedicated on July 25, 1925 by [[Harvey Firestone]], the founder of the [[Firestone Tire and Rubber Company]]. It was owned and operated by the Firestone company until it was donated to the City of Akron in 1988. It has a seating capacity of 4,576. From 1999 to 2017, it served as the home of the [[Akron Racers]] of the [[National Pro Fastpitch]] softball league. The stadium has been the site of the annual [[Mid-American Conference Softball Tournament]] since 2008, after previously hosting it from 2002 to 2005.{{cite book |url= http://mac-sports.com/documents/2016/3/24/2016_SB_Record_Book.pdf |title= MAC Softball Record Book |publisher=[[Mid-American Conference]] |format= PDF|date=March 24, 2016 |accessdate=May 11, 2016 |pages=27–28}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.akronracers.org/stadium/atoz/ Firestone Stadium] {{National Pro Fastpitch stadiums}} [[Category:Softball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Ohio]] [[Category:Sports venues in Akron, Ohio]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1925]] [[Category:1925 establishments in Ohio]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Akron, Ohio]] {{Ohio-baseball-venue-stub}}

52,958 (2003–present) }} '''Franklin Field''' is the home of the [[Penn Relays]], and is the [[University of Pennsylvania]]'s stadium for [[American football|football]], [[track and field]], [[lacrosse]] and formerly for [[soccer]], [[field hockey]] and [[baseball]]. It is also used by Penn students for recreation, and for [[intramural]] and [[college athletics|club sports]], including [[touch football (American)|touch football]] and [[cricket]], and is the site of Penn's graduation exercises, weather permitting. Franklin Field is located in [[Philadelphia]], at the eastern edge of Penn's campus, across the [[Schuylkill River]] from [[Center City, Philadelphia|Center City]]. Deemed by the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] as the oldest stadium still operating for football, it was the site of the nation's first scoreboard in 1895, the nation's first stadium with an upper deck of seats in 1922, and was the site of the first radio broadcast of a football game in 1922 on [[WTEL (AM)|WIP]] and the first television broadcast of a football game by [[KYW-TV|Philco]].http://www.pennathletics.com/page/franklin-field From 1958 until 1970, the stadium was the home field of the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] of the [[National Football League]]. ==History== [[File:FranklinField1922.PNG|thumb|left|200px| Workmen laying bricks on south wall of Franklin Field circa 1922.]] Franklin Field was built for {{USD|100000|1895}} and dedicated on April 20, 1895, for the first running of the [[Penn Relays]]. The Field supplemented and eventually replaced the venue called '''University Grounds''', which was located a few blocks west on a block bounded by Spruce Street (north), 38th Street (east), Pine Street (south), Woodland Avenue and 37th Street T-intersection (northwest). Its location was typically given as "37th and Spruce".http://www.archives.upenn.edu/img/alum/blkly1894x600.jpg Permanent Franklin Field construction did not begin until after the turn of the century. Weightman Hall gymnasium, the stadium, and permanent grandstands were designed by architect [[Frank Miles Day|Frank Miles Day & Brother]] and were erected from 1903 to 1905 at a cost of {{USD|500000|1905}}. The field was 714 feet long and 443 feet wide. The site featured a ¼-mile track, a football field, and a baseball diamond. Beneath the stands were indoor tracks and indoor training facilities.{{cite book |last=Nitzsche|first=George E.|title=University of Pennsylvania: Its History, Traditions, Buildings and Memorials|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CWYgAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA186&lpg=PA186&dq=%22Weightman+Hall%22&source=bl&ots=2ReAZ8GC-W&sig=bDzE58YjLmlHn9vWBPIGS6nO7N4&hl=en&ei=b-76SZvtJcOFtgeJn7naBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5#PPA186,M1|publisher=International Publishing Company|year=1918|location=Philadelphia|edition=Seventh |isbn=|pages=186}} In 1916, university officials, led by George Neitzche, planned with the city to build a new 100,000-seat half-sunken stadium for $750,000 at Woodland Ravine, a depression on the southeastern side of [[The Woodlands (Philadelphia)|Woodland Cemetery]]. Plans called for a new train station called Union Station which would feature a [[Pennsylvania Railroad]] stop and a stop on a proposed (and never built) elevated subway line connected to the [[Market–Frankford Line]]. Architecture firm Koronski & Cameron created a rendering but plans quickly collapsed. Five years later, it was decided instead to expand Franklin Field.{{cite news |first= |last=|title=99 Years Ago in Philadelphia: Middle of February, 1916|date=2015-02-18|publisher=Philaphilia|url =http://philaphilia.blogspot.com/2015/02/99-years-ago-in-philadelphia-middle-of.html|accessdate=2015-03-11}} The current stadium structure was built in the 1920s, designed by Day & Klauder, after the original wooden bleachers were torn down. The lower tier was erected in 1922. The old wood stands were razed immediately following the Penn Relays and the new concrete lower tier and seating for 50,000 were built.{{cite news |title=PENN CANNOT BE HOST.; Changes at Franklin Field Bar Track for Intercollegiates.|date=1922-01-08|work=[[New York Times]]|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1922/01/08/107044252.pdf|pages=120|accessdate=2009-04-17 |format=PDF}} The second tier was added in 1925, again designed by [[Charles Klauder|Day & Klauder]], when it became the second (and the largest) two-tiered stadium in the United States.{{cite news |first=Mary D. |last=McConaghy|author2=Michael T. Woods |title=Penn Sports in the 1800s: The Origins of Penn Athletics|year=2005|publisher=[[University of Pennsylvania]]: University Archives and Records Center |url=http://www.archives.upenn.edu/histy/features/sports/sports1800s.html|accessdate=2009-01-08}} [[File:Penn - Franklin Field - 1922.jpg|thumb|left|200px| Franklin Field upon completion in 1922.]] The first football radio broadcast originated from Franklin Field in 1922. It was carried by Philadelphia station [[WTEL (AM)|WIP]]. This claim is pre-empted by an earlier live radio broadcast emanating from Forbes Field in Pittsburgh, on October 8, 1921, a full year before Franklin Field's claim to fame. Harold W. Arlin announced the live broadcast of the Pitt-West Virginia football game on October 8, 1921, on radio station KDKA. The first commercial football television broadcast in 1939 also came from Franklin Field. The [[1936 Democratic National Convention]] was concluded at Franklin Field, where President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] delivered his acceptance speech after being renominated for a second term. In the university's football heyday—when Penn led the nation in attendance—the 65,000-seat stadium was expanded each fall with temporary stands to seat 78,000. Today, Franklin Field, named after Penn's founder, [[Benjamin Franklin]], seats 52,958. Franklin Field switched from grass to AstroTurf in 1969. It was the first National Football League stadium to use artificial turf. The stadium's fifth AstroTurf surface was installed in 1993. The current Sprinturf field replaced the AstroTurf in 2004.{{cite news|first=Michael|last=Gertner|title=Franklin Field features new turf, scoreboard|date=2004-09-02|work=[[Daily Pennsylvanian]]|url=http://media.www.dailypennsylvanian.com/media/storage/paper882/news/2004/09/02/Sports/Franklin.Field.Features.New.Turf.Scoreboard-2151153.shtml|accessdate=2008-12-17|language=}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Franklin Field was considered a candidate to host games for the [[1994 FIFA World Cup|1994 World Cup]]. [[FIFA]] required that host stadiums have natural grass. Had Philadelphia been selected and Franklin Field used, the stadium would have had to return to a grass surface,{{cite news |title=Franklin Field May Get Grass if Phila. Gets World Cup Soccer|date=1989-07-15|work=[[Philadelphia Inquirer]] |page=D01}} or perhaps use a temporary grass field as was done at two World Cup sites—[[Giants Stadium]] in [[East Rutherford, New Jersey]], and the [[Pontiac Silverdome]] in [[Pontiac, Michigan]]. ==Track and field== [[File:FranklinField.JPG|thumb|left|200px|Fieldhouse at the west end of the field]] ===Penn Relays=== {{details|Penn Relays}} Franklin Field has hosted the annual [[Penn Relays|Penn Relays Carnival]], the largest track-and-field meet in the U.S., for over 100 years. The first Penn Relays was held in 1895. Frank B. Ellis, chairman of Penn's track committee, was looking for an event to mark the dedication of the school's then new stadium, Franklin Field. Two years earlier, during his senior year at Penn, Penn and [[Princeton University|Princeton]] competed in a one-mile relay race in which four runners from each school each ran a quarter of a mile. That race had been an outgrowth of intramural relay races held at Penn. Ellis and others arranged a series of relay races to take place on Saturday afternoon, April 20, 1895. 64 competitors from eight colleges, six prep schools and two high schools took part. Eight two-team races were run with Harvard beating Penn in the mile-relay feature in 3:34.4.{{cite news| first=| last=| title=The Relays!| date=1955-05-02| work=[[Sports Illustrated]]| url=http://vault.sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1069475/1/index.htm| pages=| accessdate=2009-01-08| language=| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120717170006/http://vault.sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1069475/1/index.htm| archivedate=2012-07-17| df=}} The Relays were featured in the April 29, 1961, premiere of [[ESPN on ABC|ABC]]'s ''[[Wide World of Sports (US TV series)|Wide World of Sports]]''. ===Other meets=== The 2nd [[Soviet Union|USSR]]-United States [[Track and field athletics|Track and Field]] dual meet was held at Franklin Field on July 18 and 19, 1959. Stars who competed included [[Parry O'Brien]], [[Ray Norton]], [[Al Cantello]], [[Hayes Jones]], [[Tamara Press]], [[Vasili Kuznetsov (athlete)|Vasili Kuznetsov]], [[Dyrol Burleson]], [[Greg Bell (athlete)|Greg Bell]], a young [[Wilma Rudolph]], and future long-jump great [[Igor Ter-Ovanesyan]].{{cite news | first=| last=ATF Editor| title=This Day in Track & Field: July 18–19 | date=2008-05-22| publisher=American Track & Field | url =http://www.american-trackandfield.com/read_feature/day-track-field| pages = | accessdate = 2009-01-08 | language = }} Franklin Field hosted the [[NCAA Men's Outdoor Track and Field Championship]] in June 1961, the first time the championship was held on the [[East Coast of the United States|East Coast]]. Seven records were set, and the [[USC Trojans|University of Southern California]] won its 21st team Track & Field championship.{{cite news| first=Roy| last=Terrell| title=The Ncaa Visits The Wild East| date=1961-06-26| work=[[Sports Illustrated]]| url=http://vault.sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1072717/1/index.htm| pages=| accessdate=2009-01-08| language=| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120718141145/http://vault.sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1072717/1/index.htm| archivedate=2012-07-18| df=}} Following the [[Montreal]] [[1976 Summer Olympics]] and in honor of the [[United States Bicentennial]], Franklin Field hosted The Bicentennial Meet of Champions track and field event on August 4, 1976. Montreal Olympians at the meet included [[Hasely Crawford]], [[Don Quarrie]], [[Michael Shine]] and [[Edwin Moses]]. The meet was also a chance for top runners including [[Houston McTear]] who had not been able to compete in Montreal to race against medal winners.{{cite news | first=| last=[[Associated Press]]| title=Olympic medalists in Bicentennial meet| date=1976-08-04| publisher=[[The Daily Courier (Arizona)|The Prescott Courier]] | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=886&dat=19760804&id=-R0LAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UFADAAAAIBAJ&pg=5888,4874152| pages = | accessdate = 2009-07-06 | language = }} 13,722 attended the event and saw [[Dwight Stones]] set a record for the high-jump and [[John Walker (athlete)|John Walker]] win the mile.{{cite news | first=Dan| last=Berger| title=Stones aims higher| date=1976-08-05| publisher=[[The Free Lance–Star]] | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1298&dat=19760805&id=sQ0UAAAAIBAJ&sjid=D4sDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4826,3522960| page =8 | accessdate = 2009-07-06 | language = }} The University of Pennsylvania hosted the two-day [[Liberty Bell Classic|1980 Liberty Bell Track and Field Classic]], an alternate to the [[1980 Summer Olympics]] for 26 countries participating in the [[1980 Summer Olympics boycott|American-led boycott of the 1980 Summer Olympics]] which were held in Moscow. The Liberty Bell Classic began on July 16, 1980. It was the largest international track meet held in the U.S. since the [[1932 Summer Olympics]] in terms of the number of foreign competitors. Franklin Field hosted the track and field events where 20,111 spectators saw the final evening of competitions. In several events, the times were better than those in Moscow, such as American [[Renaldo Nehemiah]]'s time of 13.31 in the 110m hurdles ahead of East German gold medal winner [[Thomas Munkelt]]'s time of 13.39.{{cite news| first=Craig| last=Neff| title=...and Meanwhile In Philadelphia: Half a world from Lenin Stadium, boycotting athletes, some of whom gave Olympian performances, proved there's no alternative to the Games| date=1980-07-28| work=[[Sports Illustrated]]| url=http://vault.sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1123636/index.htm| pages=| accessdate=2009-06-15| language=| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121202235510/http://vault.sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1123636/index.htm| archivedate=2012-12-02| df=}} ===Track configuration=== The track in Franklin Field has a rarely used configuration where the 400 metre circumference is achieved in lane 5, rather than in lane one. Thus there are two curbs on the track, inside of lane one and also inside of lane 5. In order to accommodate the full fields of the Penn Relays and other meets, special adaptations are made with a movable curb on the backstretch to stagger the runners to arrive at a common break point in lane 5, rather than the conventional lane one. Single lap races in the inner lanes, run portions of an extra straightaway. Multiple lap races spend the majority of the race in lane 5 to run the proper distances.http://sites.google.com/site/collegeovalscom/ivy-league/franklin-field The current track was installed in 2015 by [http://www.attsports.com/ ATT Sports, Inc.], and uses a Rekortan track surface. ==Football== [[File:FranlkinField2.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Franklin Field]] ===Penn Quakers=== Penn football played on Franklin Field for the first time in 1895. The University of Pennsylvania was one of the top football schools in the first years of college football. Many consider Penn to have been the national champion in college football in 1894, 1895, 1897 and 1904.{{cite book |title=Fight On, Pennsylvania |last=Rottenberg |first=Dan |year=1985 |publisher=Trustees of University of Pennsylvania |location=Philadelphia |pages=28, 33–34}} Other sources identify Penn as national champions in 1895, 1897, 1904 and 1908.{{cite web |title=College Football National Champions |url=http://www.collegefootballpoll.com/champions_national.html |publisher=collegefootballpoll.com |accessdate=2009-06-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708175404/http://www.collegefootballpoll.com/champions_national.html |archivedate=2011-07-08 |df= }} [[John H. Outland]] played at Franklin Field for Penn in 1897 and 1898. On October 26, 1907, [[Jim Thorpe]] and the [[Carlisle Indian Industrial School|Carlisle Indian school]] trounced a powerful University of Pennsylvania team, 26-6, before an overflow crowd of 20,000 at Franklin Field.{{cite news |title=15 Most memorable Phila. sports moments. |date=2009-05-09 |newspaper=Philadelphia Inquirer |url=http://www.philly.com/philly/news/nation_world/20090529_During_The_Inquirer_s_180_years__a_city_that_loves_NO_HEAD_SPECIFIED.html |accessdate=2009-11-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090926082141/http://www.philly.com/philly/news/nation_world/20090529_During_The_Inquirer_s_180_years__a_city_that_loves_NO_HEAD_SPECIFIED.html |archivedate=September 26, 2009}} [[Red Grange]] set an NCAA record at Franklin Field when he rushed for 331 yards{{cite news |title=Franklin Field |publisher=[[Ivy League|The Ivy League]] |url=http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/documents/02pennfbv.asp |accessdate=2009-01-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080411232215/http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/documents/02pennfbv.asp |archivedate=April 11, 2008}} in the [[Illinois Fighting Illini football|University of Illinois]]' 24–2 victory over Penn on October 31, 1925, before 67,877 spectators.{{cite news |title=All-Time Scores: 1925 |date=July 2008 |publisher=University of Illinois Athletics |url=http://fightingillini.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/archive/AllTimeScores.html |accessdate=2009-01-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081216045848/http://fightingillini.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/archive/AllTimeScores.html |archivedate=2008-12-16 |df= }} On Saturday, November 16, 2002, [[ESPN]] broadcast [[College GameDay (football)|College GameDay]] from Franklin Field prior to the game between Penn and [[Harvard Crimson|Harvard]]. Both teams entered the game undefeated, 5–0, in the conference. It was College GameDay's first broadcast from a [[NCAA Division I Football Championship|Division I-AA]] college.{{cite news |title=Yo! Who's No. 1? |date=2002-11-19 |publisher=[[Ivy League|The Ivy League]] |url=http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/article.asp?intID=1950 |accessdate=2009-01-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060614182809/http://ivyleaguesports.com/article.asp?intID=1950 |archivedate=June 14, 2006}} Penn won the contest, 44–9, and was undefeated and untied for the season. Harvard finished 6–1 in conference, 7–3 overall.{{cite news |author=Harvard Athletic Communications|title=Gridders Take A Fall In Philadelphia |date=2002-11-16 |publisher=GoCrimson.com |url=http://www.gocrimson.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=41070&SPID=3659&DB_OEM_ID=9000&ATCLID=679219 |accessdate=2009-01-05}} {{dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The Penn Quakers football team played their 800th game ever at the stadium on October 4, 2008, against [[Dartmouth Big Green|Dartmouth]].{{cite news|first=Andy |last=Kuhn|title=Franklin Field 800: On Saturday, Quakers host 800th football game at facility for which they're 'caretakers'|date=2008-10-02|work=[[Daily Pennsylvanian]]|url=http://media.www.dailypennsylvanian.com/media/storage/paper882/news/2008/10/02/Sports/Franklin.Field.800-3465500.shtml |accessdate=2009-01-22|language=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081004051317/http://media.www.dailypennsylvanian.com/media/storage/paper882/news/2008/10/02/Sports/Franklin.Field.800-3465500.shtml|archivedate=2008-10-04}} ===Philadelphia Eagles=== The [[Philadelphia Eagles]] played at Franklin Field from [[1958 NFL season|1958]] through [[1970 NFL season|1970]]. They moved to the stadium for the 1958 season after leaving [[Connie Mack Stadium]]. Franklin Field would seat over 60,000 for the Eagles whereas Connie Mack had a capacity of 39,000. According to then-Eagles president Frank L. McNamee, the Eagles did not pay rent for use of Franklin Field because Penn was a not-for-profit organization. Instead, the Eagles donated between $75,000 and $100,000 per-year to pay for maintenance and other expenses. The university collected all concessions and parking revenue. On October 11, 1959, NFL Commissioner [[Bert Bell]] died after suffering a [[Myocardial infarction|heart attack]] at Franklin Field during the last two minutes of the game between the Eagles and [[Pittsburgh Steelers]].{{cite news |title=NFL History by Decade: 1950-1959|publisher=[[National Football League|NFL]] |url=http://www.nfl.com/history/chronology/1951-1960 |accessdate=2009-01-05}} The Eagles hosted the [[1960 NFL Championship Game]] here, defeating the [[Green Bay Packers]], 17–13,{{cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/196012260phi.htm|title=Green Bay Packers at Philadelphia Eagles – December 26, 1960|accessdate=2009-04-13 |publisher=[[Pro Football Reference]]}} in Packers' coach [[Vince Lombardi]]'s only career playoff loss. Attendance for the championship was 67,325.{{cite news|first=Tex|last=Maule|title=A Big Run Wins For A Big Defense|date=1961-01-09|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|url=http://vault.sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1072148/index.htm |accessdate=2009-04-13|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120722210014/http://vault.sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1072148/index.htm|archivedate=2012-07-22}} Two infamous incidents in Eagles history occurred at the stadium. ====Santa Claus booed==== During the December 15, 1968 game against the [[Minnesota Vikings]], a Christmas show was planned for halftime. The Eagles had entered the game 2–11, and fans were none too pleased with Eagles quarterback [[Norm Snead]], owner [[Jerry Wolman]], and especially coach [[Joe Kuharich]]: many fans came to the game wearing "Joe Must Go" buttons. Unfortunately, the man meant to play Santa was unable to make it to Franklin Field due to the bad weather. In lieu of the original halftime show, a 19-year-old fan named Frank Olivo (who came to the stadium already wearing a [[Santa Claus]] costume) was invited onto the field to toss candy canes with the cheerleaders. Frustrated by the team, the ugly wet weather, and his unconvincing beard, fans booed Olivo and threw snowballs at him. This incident is often referred to by sportscasters in denigrating Philadelphia sports fans as so mean they booed Santa Claus.{{cite news|first=Ronnie |last=Polaneczky |title=This is Philly: After 40 years, we'll still boo a bad Santa |date=2008-12-15 |work=[[Philadelphia Daily News]] |url=http://www.philly.com/philly/hp/news_update/20081215_Ronnie_Polaneczky__This_is_Philly__After_40_years__we_ll_still_boo_a_bad_Santa.html |accessdate=2008-12-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081216034235/http://www.philly.com/philly/hp/news_update/20081215_Ronnie_Polaneczky__This_is_Philly__After_40_years__we_ll_still_boo_a_bad_Santa.html |archivedate=December 16, 2008}} The Eagles lost the game, 24–17.{{cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/196812150phi.htm|title=Minnesota Vikings at Philadelphia Eagles – December 15, 1968|accessdate=2009-04-13 |publisher=[[Pro Football Reference]]}} (Olivo continued to attend Eagles games and even made a return as Santa Claus four decades later, at the Eagles' December 27, 2009 game against the [[Denver Broncos]] at [[Lincoln Financial Field]].){{cite news|first=Kerith |last=Gabriel |title='Santa' recalls Eagles 1968 snowball incident |date=2009-12-28 |newspaper=Philadelphia Daily News |url=http://www.philly.com/philly/sports/20091228_Joseph_Santoliquito___Santa__recalls_Eagles_1968_snowball_incident.html |accessdate=2009-12-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091231032211/http://www.philly.com/philly/sports/20091228_Joseph_Santoliquito___Santa__recalls_Eagles_1968_snowball_incident.html |archivedate=December 31, 2009}} ====Howard Cosell taken ill==== On November 23, 1970, announcer [[Howard Cosell]] was apparently drunk during a nationally televised broadcast of the Eagles-[[New York Giants]] ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' game. After throwing up on [[color commentator]] [[Don Meredith]]'s cowboy boots shortly before halftime, Cosell left the stadium and took a taxi back to New York City. Meredith and [[play-by-play]] announcer [[Keith Jackson]] made little mention of his departure during the second half. Later, denying drunkenness, Cosell claimed that he had been dizzy from running laps around Franklin Field's track before the game with track star [[Tommie Smith]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2007}} ===Other college football=== [[File:ArmyNavy1908.jpeg|right|thumb|500px|1908 Army–Navy game at Franklin Field]] The [[Army–Navy Game]] was played 18 times at Franklin Field between 1899 and 1935 before moving to the larger [[Philadelphia Municipal Stadium|Municipal Stadium]] in South Philadelphia in 1936.{{cite book |last1=Didinger |first1=Ray |last2=Lyons |first2=Robert S. |title=The Eagles Encyclopedia |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yV7lvstPuqgC&pg=PA205&dq=%22Franklin+Field%22+penn |accessdate=2009-01-08 |year=2005 |publisher=Temple University Press |location=Philadelphia |isbn=1-59213-449-1|page=205}} Penn alumnus and Olympic-medalist [[George Orton]] (who had worked with Frank Ellis in managing the Penn Relays) is credited with helping to bring the game to Philadelphia in 1899.{{cite web|title=George Washington Orton (1873–1958)|work=Penn Biographies |publisher=University of Pennsylvania Archives|url=http://www.archives.upenn.edu/people/1800s/orton_geo_w.html|accessdate=2009-04-30}} Temple University played its home football games at [[Temple Stadium]] until the late 1970s. Temple Stadium had opened in 1928 and sat up to 34,000 for football. Over the years, Temple had played home games at Franklin Field when crowds were expected to exceed Temple Stadium's capacity. Temple moved its home games to [[Veterans Stadium]] in the late 1970s but the [[Philadelphia Phillies|Phillies]] had priority for the field for Saturdays during baseball season, which ends the last week in September. When Temple home games conflicted with Phillies home games, Temple would play at Franklin Field. This continued through the 2002 season, Temple's final year at the Vet before the Owls moved to [[Lincoln Financial Field]] as tenants of the [[Philadelphia Eagles|Eagles]].{{cite news |first=David |last=Burrick |title=Franklin Field done serving as Owls' nest |url=http://media.www.dailypennsylvanian.com/media/storage/paper882/news/2003/09/12/Sports/Franklin.Field.Done.Serving.As.Owls.Nest-2154018.shtml |work=[[The Daily Pennsylvanian]] |date=2003-09-12 |accessdate=2009-06-19}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}} One of the last Temple football games at Franklin Field was a 44–21 loss to the number-one-ranked [[2002 Miami Hurricanes football team|Miami Hurricanes]] on September 14, 2002; Miami's [[Willis McGahee]] rushed for 134 yards and four touchdowns in front of 33,169 fans.{{cite news|first=Dan|last=McQuade|title=Top-ranked Miami runs past Temple at Franklin Field|url=http://media.www.dailypennsylvanian.com/media/storage/paper882/news/2002/09/16/Sports/TopRanked.Miami.Runs.Past.Temple.At.Franklin.Field-2157261.shtml|work=[[The Daily Pennsylvanian]]|date=2002-09-16|accessdate=2009-06-19 |deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070514043144/http://media.www.dailypennsylvanian.com/media/storage/paper882/news/2002/09/16/Sports/TopRanked.Miami.Runs.Past.Temple.At.Franklin.Field-2157261.shtml|archivedate=2007-05-14|df=}} In [[2016 NCAA Division III football season|2016]], the multi-division [[Eastern College Athletic Conference]] (ECAC) held the second installment of its six [[NCAA Division III]] post-season [[bowl game]]s (over three days) at Franklin Field for select member teams that did not make the DIII playoffs. In the series's inaugural year, the games were played at [[Arute Field]] in [[New Britain, Connecticut]]. The bowl series will move to [[Delaware Stadium]] in [[2017 NCAA Division III football season|2017]], but will return to Franklin Field in [[2018 NCAA Division III football season|2018]].http://www.ecacsports.com/news/2017/5/31/football-ecac-d3-fb-fest-sites-announced-for-2017-18.aspx ===Other professional football=== The [[National Football League|NFL]]'s [[Frankford Yellow Jackets]] hosted the [[Dayton Triangles]] on September 24, 1927, at Franklin Field. The Yellow Jackets usually played their home games in the [[Frankford, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Frankford]] section of Philadelphia.{{cite news|first=John J.|last=Fenton |title=Philadelphia's Pro Football Stadiums|date=2001–2007|publisher=Ghosts of the Gridiron|url=http://home.comcast.net/~ghostsofthegridiron/stadiums.htm |accessdate=2009-01-13|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081214135544/http://home.comcast.net/~ghostsofthegridiron/stadiums.htm |archivedate=2008-12-14}} The Triangles won, 6–3.{{cite news |title=1927 Dayton Triangles Game Results|date=2000–2008|publisher=Pro Football Reference |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/day/1927_games.htm|accessdate=2009-01-13}} On August 23, 1958, the first [[Canadian Football League]] game played on American soil between two Canadian teams was played at Franklin Field, as the [[Hamilton Tiger-Cats]] defeated the [[Ottawa Rough Riders]], 13–7.{{cite news |first=Tony|last=Guadagnoli|title=Football's oldest stadiums: Witnesses to the game's evolution|date=2008-10-05|publisher=[[ESPN]] |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/travel/news/story?id=3620761&lpos=spotlight&lid=tab8pos1|accessdate=2008-10-16}} The [[Philadelphia Bell]] of the [[World Football League]] played their 1975 season home games at Franklin Field. Franklin Field hosted two [[United States Football League]] play off games; divisional playoff game on June 30, 1984, between the host [[Philadelphia/Baltimore Stars|Philadelphia Stars]] and the visiting [[New Jersey Generals]]. The Stars were forced to play the game at Franklin Field because the [[Philadelphia Phillies]] had a game scheduled at [[Veterans Stadium]] that weekend. The Stars defeated the Generals, 28–7, behind two touchdowns from RB [[Kelvin Bryant]]. A crowd of 19,038 took in the game on a warm, overcast afternoon.{{cite news |title=1984 USFL Quarterfinals|publisher=OurSportsCentral.com/usfl |url=http://www.oursportscentral.com/usfl/84quart.htm|accessdate=2009-01-05}} The game was broadcast nationally on [[ABC Sports]]. The Eastern Conference championship game the following weekend against the [[Birmingham Stallions]] was also moved to Franklin, due to a Phillies game, and also broadcast on ABC. ==Other sports== [[File:Franklin Field (Philadelphia)-exterior.JPG|thumb|left|200px|The arched exterior of Franklin Field]] Franklin Field served as Penn's baseball field early in its history, as records show that the varsity played here from 1895{{cite news |first=Michael T. |last=Woods|title=Penn Baseball in the 1800s: 1895 Varsity Team |date=August 2005|publisher=[[University of Pennsylvania]]: University Archives |url=http://www.archives.upenn.edu/histy/features/sports/baseball/1800s/1895.html|accessdate=2009-01-27}} until at least 1924.{{cite news |title=PENN BEATS YALE IN STRAW HAT GAME; Ten Thousand Baseball Fans, Many in Summer Head Dress, See Favorites Win, 8-5.|date=1924-05-24|work=[[New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1924/05/04/archives/penn-beats-yale-in-straw-hat-game-ten-thousand-baseball-fans-many.html|pages =S2 |accessdate=2009-04-17}} Franklin Field was the longtime home of Philadelphia's City Title high school football championship game. The game was held at the stadium in 1938, 1940, 1941, and from 1943 through 1972, before it moved to [[Veterans Stadium]]. On [[Thanksgiving (United States)|Thanksgiving Day]], 1941, 40,000 fans watched [[West Philadelphia High School|West Philadelphia]] tie [[West Philadelphia Catholic High School for Boys|West Philadelphia Catholic]], 0–0. In 1945, 54,000 fans saw [[South Philadelphia High School|Southern]] beat [[West Philadelphia Catholic High School for Boys|West Catholic]], 18–13. The 1946 game, played before 60,000, ended in a riot when [[Northeast High School (Philadelphia, Pennsylvania)|Northeast]] fans stormed the field in the final minute of the school's 33–26 victory over [[West Philadelphia Catholic High School for Boys|West Catholic]], prompting West Catholic fans to do the same.{{cite web |url=http://www.tedsilary.com/FBCitytitlegames.htm|title=FB City Title Recaps|accessdate=2009-04-23 |work=tedsillary.com|publisher=Ted Sillary|date=}} The [[North American Soccer League (1968–84)|NASL]] [[Philadelphia Atoms]] had played at [[Veterans Stadium]] from [[1973 North American Soccer League season|1973]]–[[1975 North American Soccer League season|1975]]. They moved to Franklin Field in [[1976 North American Soccer League season|1976]] which had better sight lines for soccer. Attendance was 8,400 for the home opener on May 2, 1976. They drew a season high of 25,000 for the July 17 match against the [[New York Cosmos (1971–1985)|New York Cosmos]] which featured soccer great [[Pele]]. The team averaged 6,449 at Franklin Field for their 11 home matches in 1976.{{cite news |first=Steve |last=Holroyd|title=Philadelphia atoms History: 1976 |publisher=PhiladelphiaAtoms.com|url=http://www.philadelphiaatoms.com/history5.htm|pages=|accessdate=2009-01-22}} The [[Philadelphia Fury (1978–80)|Philadelphia Fury]] hosted a play-off game against the [[Tampa Bay Rowdies (1975–93)|Tampa Bay Rowdies]] on August 23, 1979, at Franklin Field when the Fury's home field, Veterans Stadium, was being used by the Phillies.{{cite news |first=Mike|last=Tierney|title=Luck writes Rowdies' playoff script|date=1979-08-22|work=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Sw0OAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UnwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6697,5000664&dq=philadelphia+fury+veterans+stadium|accessdate=2009-04-17}} Franklin Field was one of fifteen United States stadia (along with [[John F. Kennedy Stadium (Philadelphia)|John F. Kennedy Stadium]], also in Philadelphia) inspected by a five-member [[FIFA]] committee in April 1988 in the evaluation of the United States as a possible host of the [[1994 FIFA World Cup]].{{cite news |first=George|last=Vecsey|title=Sports of The Time; Americans Prepare for Lights, Cameras and Soccer|date=1988-04-10|work=[[New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/04/10/sports/sports-of-the-time-americans-prepare-for-lights-cameras-and-soccer.html?n=Top/Reference/Times%20Topics/People/V/Vecsey,%20George|accessdate=2009-04-24}} On August 25, 1989, a crowd of 43,356 at Franklin Field saw the [[United States men's national soccer team|US national soccer team]] defeat [[FC Dnipro Dnipropetrovsk|Dnepr]] of the [[Soviet Top League]], 1–0; [[Eric Eichmann]] scored the lone goal in the game's 12th minute.{{cite news |agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=RESULTS PLUS |date=1989-08-26|work=[[New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/26/sports/results-plus-632589.html?sec=&spon=|accessdate=2009-04-13}} On November 30, 2004, Franklin Field was home to the first [[rugby league]] match between the [[United States national rugby league team|United States]] and [[Australian national rugby league team|Australia]]. The United States led the [[Rugby League World Cup|World Cup]]-holders Australia for much of the game, but eventually lost, 36–24.{{cite news|first=Jonathan|last=Tannenwald|title=U.S. Rugby's upset bid spoiled by Australia at Franklin Field|date=2004-12-01|work=[[Daily Pennsylvanian]]|url=http://media.www.dailypennsylvanian.com/media/storage/paper882/news/2004/12/01/Sports/U.s-Rugbys.Upset.Bid.Spoiled.By.Australia.At.Franklin.Field-2149931.shtml|accessdate=2009-01-05}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}} The stadium hosted the Division I [[NCAA Men's Lacrosse Championship]] in 1973 and 1992 and the [[NCAA Women's Lacrosse Championship|NCAA Division I Women's Lacrosse Championship]] in May 2007.{{cite news|title=2007 NCAA Division I Women's Lacrosse Championship Ticket Information|date=2007-01-10|work=Draw Philadelphia |url=http://www.drawphiladelphia.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=2700&ATCLID=743954&KEY=&DB_OEM_ID=2700&DB_LANG=&IN_SUBSCRIBER_CONTENT=|accessdate=2008-10-16 |deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160107184023/http://www.drawphiladelphia.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=2700&ATCLID=743954&KEY=&DB_OEM_ID=2700&DB_LANG=&IN_SUBSCRIBER_CONTENT=|archivedate=2016-01-07}} April 14, 2012 marked the debut of Franklin Field as the home stadium for the [[Philadelphia Spinners]] in their first [[AUDL]] season. An estimated 1700 were in attendance as the Spinners defeated the [[Buffalo Hunters]], 26–14. The Spinners continued to use Franklin Field for the rest of the 2012 season and used it for two games in the 2014 [[Major League Ultimate|MLU]] season. The inaugural [[Major League Ultimate]] championship game was played at Franklin Field on July 13, 2013. The [[Boston Whitecaps]] defeated the [[San Francisco Dogfish]], 20–15. The Stadium again hosted the MLU Championship on July 16, 2016, as the [[Philadelphia Spinners]] defeated the [[Portland Stags]], 14–11. ==Other events== The stadium was the site of the speech by President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] in which he accepted the [[United States presidential election, 1936|1936]] [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]]'s nomination for a second term as president.{{cite news | first=M. Charles| last=Bakst| title=At conventions, JFK and FDR also spoke outdoors| date=2008-08-21| publisher=[[Providence Journal]] | url =http://www.projo.com/news/politics/content/BAKST_COLUMN_21_08-21-08_G3B0CE8_v10.3f6a81e.html?npc| pages = | accessdate = 2008-08-28 | language = }} It is estimated that a crowd of 100,000 sat through intermittent rain at Franklin Field to hear FDR's speech.{{cite news|first=Jeff |last=Gammage |title=Before Obama, there was FDR at Franklin Field |date=2008-08-29 |work=[[Philadelphia Inquirer]] |url=http://www.philly.com/philly/news/politics/elections/20080829_Before_Obama__there_was_FDR_at_Franklin_Field.html |pages= |accessdate=2008-08-29 |language= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081216141734/http://www.philly.com/philly/news/politics/elections/20080829_Before_Obama__there_was_FDR_at_Franklin_Field.html |archivedate=December 16, 2008 }} ===Entertainment=== [[Drum Corps International]] held its annual [[DCI Division I World Champions|Drum and Bugle Corps World Championships]] at the stadium in 1975 and 1976. In 1997, Franklin Field hosted Irish band [[U2]] during the first leg of their [[Pop Mart]] Tour on June 8. This was the stadium's first concert since the 1970s.{{cite news| first=Jaclyn| last=LaPlaca| title=Tickets on sale today for U2 at Franklin Field| date=1997-02-13| publisher=[[Daily Pennsylvanian]]| url=http://media.www.dailypennsylvanian.com/media/storage/paper882/news/1997/02/13/Resources/Tickets.On.Sale.Today.For.U2.At.Franklin.Field-2171064.shtml| pages=| accessdate=2009-01-05| language=}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite news| first=Shannon| last=Burke| title=U2 rocks Franklin Field with energized show| date=1997-06-12| publisher=[[Daily Pennsylvanian]]| url=http://media.www.dailypennsylvanian.com/media/storage/paper882/news/1997/06/12/Resources/U2.Rocks.Franklin.Field.With.Energized.Show-2172066.shtml| pages=| accessdate=2009-01-05| language=| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090204140327/http://media.www.dailypennsylvanian.com/media/storage/paper882/news/1997/06/12/Resources/U2.Rocks.Franklin.Field.With.Energized.Show-2172066.shtml| archivedate=2009-02-04| df=}} ===In Film=== The 2000 [[M. Night Shyamalan]]-directed movie ''[[Unbreakable (film)|Unbreakable]]'' prominently features Franklin Field as one of the main locations in the film. The film's main character, played by [[Bruce Willis]], plays a security guard at the stadium. In the [[2006 in film|2006]] movie ''[[Invincible (2006 film)|Invincible]]'', Franklin Field served as a stand-in for the demolished [[Veterans Stadium]], images of which were digitally superimposed on some of the football action sequences. {{coord|39|57|N|75|11.4|W|display=title}} ==See also== {{Portal|Philadelphia}} * [[List of NCAA Division I FCS football stadiums]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160820222643/http://penn-oas-web-prod.slabs-cloud.com/page/franklin-field Penn Athletics: Franklin Field] * [http://www.stadiumsofprofootball.com/past/FranklinField.htm Stadiums of Pro Football: Franklin Field] * [http://www.philadelphiabuildings.org/pab/app/pj_display.cfm/82889 Architectural photos of Franklin Field] * [http://sports.espn.go.com/travel/gallery/gallery?id=3016261 ESPN.com: Photo gallery "Oldest stadiums – Monuments to the past"] * [http://digital.hagley.org/cdm4/results.php?CISOOP1=all&CISOBOX1=franklin+field&CISOFIELD1=CISOSEARCHALL&CISOROOT=%2Fp268001uw Hagley Digital Archives: Aerial photographs of Franklin Field in 1920s and 1930s] {{S-start}} {{Succession box | title = Home of the

{{Other uses|Gamo (disambiguation)}} {{Multiple issues| {{prose|date=April 2010}} {{cleanup|date=April 2010}} {{refimprove|date=July 2016}} }} {{Infobox company | name = Gamo | logo = File:Gamo_(air_gun_manufacturer)_logo.gif | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | logo_padding = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | native_name = Industrias El Gamo S.A. | native_name_lang = <!-- Use ISO 639-1 code, e.g. "fr" for French. For multiple names in different languages, use {{lang|[code]|[name]}}. --> | former_name = | type = | industry = | founded = 1959<ref>{{cite web |title=Do-it-Yourself Scope Mounting |url=http://www.gamo.com/portal/international/History |publisher=www.gamo.com |accessdate=7 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081005094040/http://www.gamo.com/portal/international/History |archivedate=5 October 2008 |df= }}</ref> | founder = <!-- or: | founders = --> | hq_location = | hq_location_city = | hq_location_country = [[Spain]] | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = | products = | brands = | services = | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | website = {{URL|http://www.gamo.com/}} }}
[[File:GamoBigCat1200.png|thumb|right|A Gamo Big Cat 1200 in loading configuration]]
'''Gamo Outdoor [[Sociedad limitada unipersonal|S.L.U]]''', or simply '''Gamo''', is a [[Spain|Spanish]] [[airgun]] manufacturer based in [[Barcelona]], [[Spain]], and is the largest producer of airguns in [[European Union|Europe]] and the largest producer of [[airgun pellet]]s in the world. The company was founded in 1959, as '''El Gamo''', and airgun production first started in 1961. Today Gamo products include [[air rifle]]s, [[air pistol]]s, [[ammunition]] and [[optics]]. They produce primarily airguns intended for mass market.
When [[Manganese Bronze Holdings]] liquidated what remained of the gun division of the [[Birmingham Small Arms Company]] in 1986, assets including the logo and the right to use the initials "BSA" were purchased by Gamo{{CN|date=June 2017}} who have continued the air rifle business at Armoury Road, [[Small Heath]], [[Birmingham]] B11 2PP under the name '''BSA Guns (UK) Limited'''.
During the 1970s in the UK El Gamo marketed two air rifles, the ''Marksman'', a conventional [[.22 caliber|.22]] rifle with a fitted and pre-zeroed telescopic sight, and the ''Paratrooper'' repeater, a [[.177 calibre|.177]] pistol-gripped [[repeating rifle]] incorporating a tubular magazine along the top of the cylinder, and using a rising/falling breech mechanism for positioning the pellet.

{{expand language|topic=|langcode=ja|otherarticle=%E6%B5%9C%E6%9D%BE%E3%81%BE%E3%81%A4%E3%82%8A|date=May 2014}} {{expand language|topic=|langcode=simple|otherarticle|Hamamatsu festival|date=December 2016}} {{Multiple issues|{{unreferenced|date=May 2014}} {{expert needed|1=Japan|date=May 2014}} }} [[File:Hamamatsu matsuri.jpg|thumb|Hamamatsu Matsuri]] [[File:Hamamatsu festival c.JPG|thumb|right|Yatai]] '''Hamamatsu Kite Festival''' (浜松まつり) is Japanese festival in [[Hamamatsu]]. It is generally known to have multiple kites, along with a lot of kite battles through the days it is held. The festival also displays examples of Japanese culture through food, and general items available for purchase in merchant booths at the festival.
== Detail == *Tako ([[Kite]] battle) *Yatai<!--not [[Yatai (retail)]]--> *Neri Participants say "Oisho, oisho!"
In Hamamatsu, the first son's birth celebration is Hatsuiwai(初祝い).<ref>[http://hirosawa.info/archives/download/2592/]</ref>
{{-}}
=== Tako === [[File:浜松まつり.jpg|thumb|120px|Tako of Tamachi - Tagumi (田町 - た組)]] In Hamamatsu Kite Festival, the kite battle is called Takogassen(凧合戦) and is done at Takoba(凧場).
Takoba is at [[Nakatajima]] since 1967.<ref>[http://takoken.hamazo.tv/e6001276.html]</ref>
174 kites are there.<ref>[http://chuplus.jp/hamamatsuri/index.php Chunichi Newspaper]</ref>
The kite of the first son's birth celebration is called Hatsudako(初凧).<ref>[https://www2.nhk.or.jp/archives/michi/cgi/detail.cgi?dasID=D0004990854_00000 NHK]</ref>
{{-}}
=== Yatai === [[File:浜松まつり御殿屋台.JPG|thumb|120px|Yatai of Matsushiro-cho - Magumi (松城町 - マ組<ref>[https://ja-jp.facebook.com/MaZusongChengDingZhengYangHui/ 松城町凧揚会（マ組）]</ref>)]] Yatai is also called Goden-Yatai(御殿屋台).<ref>[http://hamamatsu-daisuki.net/matsuri/introduction/stall.html]</ref>
{{-}}
=== Neri === [[File:Japonsko_-_Hamamacu,_z_bitvy_draků_-_Tako_macuri_(1981).jpg|thumb|120px|Neri of Higashiiba-cho - Igumi (東伊場町 - い組)]] At the house where the eldest son is born, their family offers cooking to everyone in order to appreciate their kite flying. This is called Hatsuneri(初練り).<ref>[https://www.hamamatsu-pippi.net/shiritai/ichioshi/mimiyori/docs/2015010500462/]</ref>
In Takoba, they also do Neri in order to celebrate.

'''Right field:''' {{convert|327|ft|m|sp=us}} }} '''Hardt Field''', also known in development as the Roadrunner Baseball Complex, is a [[baseball]] [[stadium]] in [[Bakersfield, California]], United States. It is the home field of the [[Cal State Bakersfield Roadrunners baseball]] team. The stadium is located in the south-west section of the campus of Cal State Bakersfield. [[File:Hardt Field Bleachers.jpg|thumb|left|160px|Hardt Field, Home Field of the CSUB Roadrunners]] The stadium was named for Tom and Barbara Hardt. The Hardt Family Trust's $1 million gift and donation of general contracting work supported the construction of the on campus baseball training and playing facility.[http://www.calstate.edu/bot/agendas/jan09/IA.pdf Committee on Institutional Advancement] The first game played in Hardt Field was the inaugural game for the Cal State Bakersfield baseball team on February 20, 2009, between CSUB and [[Saint Louis Billikens baseball|Saint Louis]], with the Billikens beating the Roadrunners 8-7[http://www.gorunners.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=13300&ATCLID=3675004 'Runners Nearly Complete Comeback In Season Opener] before a sold-out crowd.[http://www.gorunners.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=58070&SPID=6320&DB_OEM_ID=13300&ATCLID=3673608 CSUB Baseball Opener Sold Out; Standing Room Only Tickets Available] Highlights from [[2009 Cal <onlyinclude> <!-- See [[Wikipedia talk:Featured lists]] for an explanation of this and other inclusion tags below -->[[Image:MIT 2006 Standard Prechamp Final.jpg|thumb|right|250px|An amateur DanceSport competition at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]].]] The dances that make up the '''list of DanceSport dances''' are performed competitively at amateur and professional levels throughout the world. Ten international style [[ballroom dance]]s—five Standard and five Latin—are defined by the '''[[World Dance Council]]''' (WDC), which has world-wide membership of all countries taking part in ballroom competitions.
The WDC incorporates various groupings and former titles, such as the [[World Dance and DanceSport Council]] (former title). The WDC is the governing body for international professional and amateur DanceSport. The [[World DanceSport Federation]] is, to some extent, a rival body which issues rules for amateur competitions.<ref>See the linked pages for details.</ref> The list is supplemented by nine American style dances—four Smooth and five Rhythm—which are defined by United States dance organizations, such as USA Dance, (formerly USABDA, the United States Amateur Ballroom Dancers Association).</onlyinclude>
Besides determining which dances are performed, these organizations specify many other aspects of their competitions, for instance, the [[tempo]] of music allowed and the duration of each competition round.
== WDC International style dances== Within World Dance Council international competitions are two categories of dances, ''Ballroom'' (also called Standard or Modern) and ''Latin''.<ref>This is the present WDC terminology.</ref> In England (e.g. at the [[Blackpool Dance Festival]]), the categories are traditionally called Ballroom and Latin American dances respectively. In the Ballroom dances, men typically wear [[Formal wear|evening dress]] (coattails, waistcoats and [[White tie|white bow ties]]), while women wear gowns. Partners remain in [[closed position]] throughout the dance, and movements tend to be elegant and sweeping. The ballroom dances are progressive, moving anti-clockwise round the floor.
The Latin dances are more overtly sensual, with skimpy costumes for women and tight-fitting ones for men.<ref>Originally, 1930–1960, clothing for latin dance was similar to ballroom, with at least dinner jackets and black tie for men, and simple dress for women, with skirts shorter than the ballroom gowns.</ref> More variation in movement is allowed than in the Standard dances. Close, semi-open and open figures are danced. [[Choreography]] is now extremely important. Hip action - Latin technique is required; and athletic and balletic maneuvers are incorporated which makes it into a DanceSport. Two Latin dances are progressive going counter clockwise (samba and paso doble), but there is no obligation to consistently move round the floor.<ref>Picart, 89-90, 92-96</ref>
=== Ballroom === <onlyinclude> {|border="2" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |-bgcolor="#efefef" !width="150"|Name !width="100"|WDSF tempo ([[Glossary of partner dance terms#Measures per minute|MPM]])<ref name="ISDF511">WDSF Competition Rules 2015, rules E.3.1 and E.3.2</ref> !width="100"|WDC tempo (MPM)<ref name=WDC_RULES_2014>{{cite web|title=WDC Rulebook, August 2014, section 2.1|url=http://www.wdcdance.com/downloads/WDC%20Competition%20Rules%20current%20August%202014.pdf|website=WDC|accessdate=24 May 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150416150908/http://www.wdcdance.com/downloads/WDC%20Competition%20Rules%20current%20August%202014.pdf|archivedate=16 April 2015|df=}}</ref> !width="150"|WDSF dancing time (seconds)<ref name="ISDF511" /> !width="150"|WDC dancing time (seconds)<ref name="WDC_RULES_2014" /> |- |[[Waltz (International Standard)|Waltz]]||28–30||28||90–120||90–120 |- |[[Tango (ballroom)|Tango]]||31–33||32||90–120||90–120 |- |[[Viennese Waltz]]||58–60||60||90–120 ||75–90 |- |[[Foxtrot (Dance)|Slow Foxtrot]]||28–30||28||90–120||90–120 |- |[[Quickstep]]||50–52||50||90–120||90–120 |}</onlyinclude>
=== Latin === {|border="2" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |-bgcolor="#efefef" !width="150"|Name !width="100"|WDSF tempo ([[Glossary of partner dance terms#Measures per minute|MPM]])<ref name="ISDF511" /> !width="100"|WDC tempo (MPM)<ref name="WDC_RULES_2016">"WDC Competition Rules, June 2016". World Dance Council.</ref> !width="150"|WDSF dancing time (seconds)<ref name="ISDF511" /> !width="150"|WDC dancing time (seconds)<ref name="WDC_RULES_2014" /> |- |[[Cha-cha-cha (dance)|Cha-cha-cha]]||30–32||30||90–120||90–120 |- |[[Samba (ballroom)|Samba]]||50–52||48||90–120||90–120 |- |[[Rhumba|Rumba]]||25–27||24||90–120||90–120 |- |[[Paso Doble]]||60–62||56||90–120||90–120 |- |[[Jive (dance)|Jive]]||42–44||42||90–120||90–120 |}
==American style==
The Smooth and Rhythm categories of American style DanceSport roughly correspond to the Standard and Latin categories of International style. In Smooth, dancers wear costumes not greatly dissimilar to those worn by their counterparts in Standard---Standard dresses often have prominent floats embellishing the arms and fuller skirts which are typically absent in Smooth, due to the open movement and changing arm positions requiring less restriction on the body; however, the dances themselves are significantly different as a result of influence by dancers like [[Fred Astaire]] and [[Arthur Murray]] in the years following [[World War II]]. While elegance and flow remain the goal, as in International Standard, dancers do not remain in [[closed position]] exclusively, instead breaking away from each other periodically and experimenting with open footwork. The Rhythm dances were also influenced by American dancers of the post-World War II era, but the differences between it and International Latin are more subtle. Costumes are similar, and while step patterns are not identical, movements are as free and explicitly sensual as in Latin.<ref>Picart, 90-95</ref>
===Smooth=== {|border="2" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |-bgcolor="#efefef" !width="150"|Name !width="100"|USABDA tempo ([[Glossary of partner dance terms#Measures per minute|MPM]])<ref name="USABDA35">2006-2007 USA DanceSport Rulebook, section 3.5</ref> !width="150"|USABDA dancing time (seconds)<ref name="USABDA34">2006-2007 USA DanceSport Rulebook, section 3.4</ref> |- |[[Waltz]]||28–30||90–120 |- |[[Tango (ballroom)|Tango]]||30–32||90–120 |- |[[Foxtrot (Dance)|Foxtrot]]||30–32||90–120 |- |[[Viennese Waltz]]||54||90 |}
===Rhythm=== {|border="2" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |-bgcolor="#efefef" !width="150"|Name !width="100"|USABDA tempo ([[Glossary of partner dance terms#Measures per minute|MPM]])<ref name="USABDA35" /> !width="150"|USABDA dancing time (seconds)<ref name="USABDA34" /> |- |[[Cha-cha-cha (dance)|Cha-cha-cha]]||30||90–120 |- |[[Rhumba|Rumba]]||32–36||90–120 |- |[[East Coast Swing]]||34–36||90–120 |- |[[Bolero]]||24–26||90–120 |- |[[Mambo (dance)|Mambo]]||47–51||90–120 |}
